Situation1: Be patient and understanding of each other's differences.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Story: I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the call button. My sales numbers were soaring this week—if I kept up the pace, I’d finally get that bonus. Management’s emails buzzed in my head: “Push harder, don’t let up.” But the next name on my list made my stomach twist. It was my younger brother, Sam. He’d just started his own business, and I knew he was struggling. I could almost hear his voice, tired but hopeful, from our last conversation. I was supposed to be the patient, understanding brother, the one who listened and respected his choices, not someone who pressured him for a sale. But the script was right there in front of me, and the expectation to close every possible deal pressed down on me. I wanted to help him, to be the brother he needed, but the thought of missing my target and letting my team down gnawed at me. My finger trembled, caught between dialing and deleting his number, my mind torn by the demands of both worlds.
